I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will support the preparation 
of the Asian Development Outlook (ADO) through research work in the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) headquarters, to provide views on the macroeconomic prospects for all 46 ADB developing 
member countries (DMCs) and insights into the economic issues these DMCs face. ADO content 
provides vital intelligence to policy makers in DMCs, ADB staff and shareholders, and researchers 
globally; and underpins ADB operational decisions. The ADO showcases ADB’s knowledge and 
expertise about the region.  
 
2.  The ADO is a vehicle for the knowledge and operational work of multiple departments 
across ADB. Country chapters in part III of the ADO, authored by country teams in the regional 
departments, discuss recent developments and the near-term outlook and risks to support the 
development of appropriate policies for macroeconomic stability. The chapters’ policy challenge 
sections include analysis of key obstacles to inclusive economic growth and poverty reduction. 
The theme chapters in part II of the ADO tackle important development challenges.1 Theme 
chapter topics for  the  next  3 years  will  include  domestic  resource mobilization,  innovative 
entrepreneurship, and achieving green growth, among others. When possible, the ADO integrates 
gender analysis and sex-disaggregated data to ensure that analysis captures and reflects key 
gender disparities.2 The TA cluster is thus mapped to the following Strategy 2030 Operational 
Priorities: (i) accelerating progress in gender equality (Operational Priority 2); (ii) tackling climate 
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability 
(Operational Priority 3); and (iii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity (Operational 
Priority 6). ADO content is expected to inform discussion on these important issues. However, as 
this corporate TA is intended to support the production of ADB flagship knowledge products and 
services, it will not directly contribute to any of the corporate results framework indicators of the 
Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities. 
 
3.  ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) submitted the 
TA to the Strategy, Policy and Partnerships Department (SPD) through the Work Program and 
Budget Framework, 2021–2023 as part of ERCD’s priority TA program. SPD endorsed the TA as 
a corporate priority TA on 22 January 2021.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has stalled developing Asia’s considerable progress 
in  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in  2000–2019.4 From  2000 to  2019, the  region 
averaged 6.6% annual growth and nearly doubled its share of world gross domestic product from 
20% to 37% in 2019. As a result, Asia made good progress in reducing extreme poverty, with the 
number of people living on less than $1.90 a day declining from 1.2 billion people in 1999 to 203 
million in 2017. Developing Asia transitioned from a region consisting of low-income economies 
 
1  ADO theme chapters are led by a team from ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
(ERCD), often with participation and inputs from the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
(SDCC) and other departments.  
2  Examples of this in recent ADO reports include discussion of the increasing role of women in agriculture in the 
September 2021 ADO Update theme chapter “Transforming Agriculture in Asia”; how green and social finance can 
support gender equity in the April 2021 ADO theme chapter “Financing a Green and Inclusive Recovery”; and 
exploring gender differences in wellness in the September 2020 ADO Update theme chapter “Wellness in Worrying 
Times”. Various policy challenge sections in Part III of the ADO also discuss gender issues and present sex-
disaggregated data. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 September 2021. 
4  Developing Asia refers to ADB’s 46 DMCs.

2 
to one dominated by middle-income economies, with about 80% of the DMCs enjoying middle-
class status in 2015.5 Despite this progress, poverty remains a key issue in developing Asia, with 
one in three people in the region—close to 1.24 billion—still living on $3.20 or less a day. The 
pandemic has set back developing Asia’s progress and has wreaked havoc on poor communities. 
The large pandemic-induced drops in economic activity in 2020 pushed an additional 78.3 million 
people into extreme poverty relative to a no-COVID scenario, and the recovery has been hindered 
by continued outbreaks.6 The main challenge for many DMCs is how to contain the pandemic; 
revive growth and poverty reduction; and address continuing challenges such as inequality, 
climate change and environmental degradation, and inadequate health and education, among 
others. Macroeconomic stability and sustained and inclusive growth are a necessary condition for 
making progress on these fronts. 
 
5.  The capacity of many DMCs to respond to these macroeconomic and development 
challenges is limited by knowledge gaps. The magnitude and nature of the recent shocks has 
made it challenging to track the current state and project the future trajectory of economies, 
making policy-making more difficult. For many policy makers, the challenges they face from the 
pandemic lack precedents that could help them formulate sound responses. After COVID-19, the 
challenges of ensuring green growth; providing adequate education, health, and social protection; 
and addressing inequality require knowledge solutions. This underscores the need for up-to-date 
research and comprehensive analyses of macroeconomic issues and development challenges 
affecting the region. As indicated in ADB’s Strategy 2030, ADB’s relevance will increasingly 
depend on its role as a knowledge institution, including its ability to generate solid, policy-relevant 
research. ADB’s knowledge and research are pivotal in increasing understanding and awareness 
about critical areas for action, supporting effective policies and reform in DMCs, and contributing 
to global development discussions by offering perspectives from the region.7  
 
6.  The TA cluster will build on the experience of the current ADO TA cluster.8 The ADO 
reports from 2019 to 2021 helped support policy dialogue and formulation. Analysis from the 2019 
ADO, for example, helped policy makers understand the potential impact on ADB DMCs of the 
trade conflict between the United States and the People’s Republic of China. The 2020 ADO 
provided estimates of the macroeconomic impact of COVID-19, which helped DMC policy makers 
calibrate their policy responses and ADB teams to design lending support appropriately. The 2021 
ADO  analysis  of  learning  and  earning losses from  COVID-19 school  closures  is informing 
education policy in the region. 
 
7.  One of the lessons learned from the previous ADO TA clusters is that there could be better 
metrics to measure the impact and reach of the ADO.9 Traditional metrics such as downloads of 
the  report  are  affected  by  the  increased  availability  of  materials  such  as  blogs,  videos, 
infographics, and summaries on the ADO landing page, which convey the ADO’s key messages 
and content without having to download the electronic copy of the publication.10 In addition, it is 
a challenge to measure whether the ADO reaches the key target audience of policymakers and

departments, utilized email dissemination to reach out to DMC policymakers more directly.11 
Another useful metric to use is the percentage of target media, both top-tier and regional, that 
published at least one story on the ADO. This has proven to be a more informative indicator of 
ADO outreach, compared to the previously adopted measurement of counting the number of 
stories published by any media outlet. The new indicator reached an average of 70% during the 
launch of ADO 2021 and ADO 2021 Update. Finally, the ADO communications strategy and 
performance indicators must recognize the increased role played by social media. In this regard, 
the TA will use the number of impressions (i.e., the number of times content related to ADO was 
displayed on social media news feeds) during the launch as another metric to measure the reach 
of the ADO. On average, ADO 2021 and ADO 2021 Update recorded about 470,000 impressions 
a month after their releases. As in the previous TA cluster, the TA will continue to monitor citation 
of the ADO in ADB documents and in research work outside ADB. Details of these indicators are 
provided in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1. 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
8.  The Macroeconomics Research Division (ERMR) of ADB’s ERCD will formulate a 2-year 
rolling research plan to ensure the quality of ADB’s flagship publications. This is an initiative that 
ERCD (previously the Economic and Research Department) began in 2011 in response to the 
growing demand for knowledge solutions from ADB DMCs, knowledge-related support from ADB, 
and an Asian voice in international forums.12 The extension of the research production process 
has proven beneficial for the ADO, especially in preparing the thematic chapters, as it allowed 
ERMR more time for in-depth analysis and rigorous peer review. The ADO will address several 
important challenges facing developing Asia, making the TA cluster approach an appropriate 
modality  to  ensure  ongoing  support  for  the  2-year  rolling  research  work  through  timely 
engagement of experts and other activities.  
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
9.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: policy discussions and research on 
challenges facing developing Asia deepened. The TA cluster will have the following outcome: 
ADO content informs policy discussions by ADB and DMC officials, views of the public, and 
analysis of researchers.13 The TA will produce the following outputs to guide ADB operational 
decisions and provide timely and relevant insights to policy makers in DMCs, ADB staff and 
shareholders, and researchers. 
 
10.  Output 1: ADO reports disseminated for 3 years (2022 –2024). The TA cluster will 
support the production of the ADO, one of ADB’s flagship publications. ERCD produces four 
issues of ADO per year—one in April, another in September, and two short supplements in July 
and December.14 This will involve (i) preparing background analytical papers following the 2-year 
rolling research plan, (ii) developing and refining analytical methods, (iii) drafting ADO content for

2022–2024, (iv) editing economic content and manuscripts, (v) preparing and laying out materials 
for publication, and (vi) disseminating key results and policy messages. The publications will be 
widely disseminated in collaboration with DOC and participating resident missions. Lessons 
learned from the implementation of the previous TA cluster—such as further coordination with the 
DOC to include better metrics for measuring the impact and reach of the ADO, improving the 
dissemination of the ADO, and other lessons—will be considered during the implementation of 
the TA cluster and its subprojects. In the absence of road shows during the pandemic, this TA will 
continue to use online platforms for disseminating ADO reports, as the previous TA cluster has 
found online means effective in reaching a wider audience that includes DMC policy makers. 
Once the situation allows, international launches will resume followed by presentations cohosted 
by ADB development partners within and outside developing Asia. Outreach will include analytical 
discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions and think tanks. The ADO 
publications will be disseminated as electronic files on the ADB website15 and sent via DOC’s 
targeted mailing list. However, as printed copies are still in demand from Management and outside 
researchers, ERCD will print a limited number (about 100) in compliance with the Administrative 
Order on Energy, Environment, Health, and Safety Management System.16 Printing of the ADO 
switched to print on demand in 2017.  
 
11.  Output 2: Background papers disseminated for 3 years (2022–2024). To provide a 
solid  empirical  and  analytical  foundation  for  ADO  content,  the  TA  cluster  will commission 
background research papers to supplement ERMR research on selected thematic topics by 
analyzing  issues  and  policy  implications  for  developing  Asia.  The  TA  team  will  organize 
workshops and seminars focusing on the thematic chapters to strengthen ADO content, and will 
invite distinguished economists to discuss initial drafts of the background papers to improve the 
analytical rigor and policy relevance of the thematic chapters. These papers may be consolidated 
in edited research volumes to provide researchers with more extensive analyses related to the 
thematic topics. The research volumes may be co-published with a reputable publishing house, 
which could entail a buyback arrangement. ADB will also publish background papers on the ADB 
website. The papers may also be published as working papers or journal articles, as appropriate.  
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $3,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7 for $1,500,000 and TASF-other sources for 
$1,500,000). Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA 
subproject proposal submitted for approval. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. ERMR will directly handle TA cluster administration 
and supervision, management of consultants, procurement, and accomplishment of outputs. 
Adopting the One ADB approach in knowledge solutions, ERMR will continue to collaborate with 
regional  departments,  including  the  resident  missions;  other  knowledge  departments;  and 
relevant sector and thematic groups on activities under each subproject. Each TA subproject 
proposal will be submitted for approval to the ERCD chief economist and director general,

15.  Consulting  services.  Individual consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be  recruited 
through individual consultant selection or framework agreements wherein shortlisted consultants 
may be hired as needed for the duration of the agreement (as may be appropriate) to provide 
international and national consulting. The TA cluster will require international consultancy from 
economists and sector specialists who will prepare background papers and analyses supporting 
the thematic chapters or topics related to the outlook. International economic advisory and editing 
consultants will be required for the economic and technical editing of the ADO manuscripts before 
final publication. National economics consultants and research assistants will be required to assist 
with data management and to conduct research on a particular topic. ADB will engage resource 
persons for a maximum of 33 working days to conduct training on macroeconomics and economic 
forecasting, serve as discussants during workshops, peer review papers, and serve as technical

The ADO covers a wide range of topics, and highly qualified consultants with expertise relevant 
to ADO requirements will most likely be associated with various research institutions, think tanks, 
and universities. Further, the TA will require rapid mobilization of the editorial consultants. The 
consultants will be engaged following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time

16.  Knowledge partnerships. ERCD  will  seek to collaborate  with  reputable  centers  of 
excellence during the conduct of research and implementation, and these may be engaged 
through knowledge partnership agreements (KPAs). ERCD will identify specific entities during TA 
cluster implementation. A nomination proposal will be prepared for proposed knowledge partners, 
and the corresponding KPA will be finalized before the approval of each TA subproject. Where 
knowledge partners are identified after TA subproject approval, ERCD will prepare a minor 
change in implementation arrangements following para. 5 of the Staff Instruction on Business 
Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance Operations and will process 
all KPAs following this staff instruction.19  
 
17.  ADB’s  procurement.  ERCD  will  procure  ICT-related  equipment  and/or  supplies, 
subscriptions to third-party databases, and statistical software under the TA, as needed and in 
coordination with the Information Technology Department and Corporate Services Department. 
Detailed implementation arrangements of ADB procurement will be finalized before the approval 
of each TA subproject. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time).20 Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time).

c  This refers to the number of times the content related to ADO was displayed on social media feeds on platforms such 
as Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, and Instagram. The performance against this indicator will be measured one month 
after the launch of the ADO and ADO Update as indicated in DOC’s media monitoring reports.  
d   This refers to the number of recipient opens of email from the ADB chief economist containing links to the ADO. This 
indicator only considers the DMC segment and often far exceeds the number of deliveries, as the direct recipients 
tend to share the ADO email further to their own contact list, which in turn is opened by many others. It is measured 
one month after the launch of the ADO and ADO Update as indicated in DOC’s publications marketing report. 
e  From 2019 to 2021, the number of background papers produced for the ADO and ADO Update theme chapters 
ranged from 7 to14.  
Contribution to Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities: 
This corporate TA is intended to support the production of ADB flagship knowledge products and services. Although 
the TA is mapped to 3 Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities (OP), OP tagging is not applicable, as agreed with the 
Strategy, Policy and Partnerships Department, since the results of the TA will not contribute directly to any of the 
corporate results framework indicators of the Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities.
